} } } Length:: 7:05 MinsThe Loftek Nexus 543 wireless security camera was surprising in the resolution, sharpness and accurate color of its image during daylight. I was also impressed with its performance at night. The Infrared LEDs did an excellent job of illumination and actually were almost too bright for the center of the image... but the majority of the rest of the image area was illuminated very well thanks to the 36 infrared LEDs surrounding the lens of this camera.The camera is housed in an aluminum enclosure that is rated IP66. This rating is about as good as it gets and means that the enclosure is dust-proof and will be able to withstand a strong, direct stream of water. In other words, this camera should be able to withstand outdoor conditions without any issues. The body is roughly the size of a 12oz can of soda. There is a hood/shield over the camera body that extends out and over the front of the camera and allows for about an inch or so of fore and aft adjustment.Out of the rear of the camera is a 2 foot long cord bundle that contains an ethernet port. Two additional wires at the end of the cord provide a power port and a reset button for the camera. The ethernet is used for initial setup of the camera and can also be used to circumvent the wireless capabilities of the camera if you want to use the camera as a wired ethernet camera instead. Power to the camera is provided by an AC adapter rated 100-240v and 50/60Hz.Because of the relatively short cord of the AC adapter wire, you would need to tap into AC power from a wall switch or fixture in close proximity to where the camera needs to be installed otherwise you would need to use extension cords which is not desirable.The mounting hardware included with the camera is lightweight duty and you might want to upgrade the mounting hardware depending on your installation needs.There is no audio capability in this particular model of camera. My video clearly demonstrates the quality of the image from the camera in day and night conditions.So for the price, this camera provides a lot of value.Setup is another matter. I have a pet peeve against poor documentation. How difficult can it be for a company to spend a few thousand dollars to have a qualified technical copywriter produce adequate documentation? The quickstart guide included with this camera is so poorly translated and written that it makes setup of this camera way more difficult than it needs to be. In fact, once I worked my way through the setup through trial and error, I realized that it's not really difficult at all, It's just that the poor documentation makes it confusing and seemingly difficult. Maybe a user with more experience with security cameras and router setup would not have experienced the problems I did, but my point is that the "average" user will more than likely run into the same difficulties that I did.Basically, if you want to use the camera strictly on your LAN... that is if you have the camera mounted outside your house and just want to be able to view the image from a computer in your house, it's relatively easy to setup. If you also want to be able to view the image from the WAN... that is from any computer on the Internet, that requires altering settings in your router which will be confusing to many people because of the poor documentation. The reality is that is also is not that difficult to do.Regarding the software that is provided with the camera... it provides basic functionality but some people may choose to use other third-party software. That's entirely up to the user.I used both a PC running Windows 8 and a Mac running Mountain Lion to setup the camera. Some of the software provided is only compatible on a PC but a PC is not required to setup the camera. The software for PC is optimized for Internet Explorer. Using any other browser will not provide complete control of the camera and no browser on the Mac will allow complete control of the camera.I am not that familiar with wireless security cameras nor the setup of same. I am also not an expert at network setup but am not a complete idiot either. I'm somewhat technically inclined, just not well-versed in the intricacies of port-forwarding and more advanced router setup procedures. Having said that, I found the procedure for getting this camera working over the WAN to be daunting. It took no less than 2 hours of putzing around before I finally "got it" largely due to the poorly written quickstart guide and marginally better documentation available on the Lofetk website.The Loftek Nexus 543 security camera is great, particularly when taking price into consideration. It's the hardware that deserves the bulk of the rating since the software can be replaced by third party software and the poor documentation can be worked around as well. So for the price the camera performs well and seems pretty well built.Since I have not had the camera very long at the time I am writing this review, I can't speak as to the long-term performance. I will update my review if necessary.I look forward to the possibility of reviewing other models of security cameras by Loftek.UPDATE: 4/12/2013: Regarding the mysterious powder that I mention in my review... I alerted the company that supplied me with the camera to that and offered to send them back the camera for further investigation. They had nothing to say except they didn't know what it was either. But apparently they didn't want to see the camera either so.......I was provided a sample for review.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, retarded software, mounting bracket from hell, connectors NOT weatherproof
Reviews.Author: J. Martin
Reviews.Content: I am giving this camera five stars because its performance is by far the best of the three relatively low-price surveillance cameras I've tried recently. It has a few peripheral flaws that I cannot bring myself to deduct stars for because they are fairly easily resolved.PROS:The image is probably as good as it gets for a cheapish VGA-resolution camera (640 x 480 pixels). The infrared optics and electronics required for nighttime imaging do not seem to detract at all from the color fidelity of the daylight image, which is excellent. Unlike an even cheaper IR camera I tried, greens are not gray, grays are not green, and blacks are not red. All colors are as they should be.The monochrome nighttime image quality is also the best I've found so far, much clearer and MUCH better detail than on the cheaper IR camera, even though its resolution was supposedly the same.The 36 IR LEDs give bright, even illumination over the entire viewing area and up to at least 30 feet (which is as far as I care about), with no noticeable concentration of light in the center as the 11 LEDS on the cheaper camera did.After initial setup with an Ethernet cable to the router (which is mandatory), I have used wireless connection exclusively with flawless results, in several different locations up to 80 feet from the router, inside and outside, with several interior and exterior walls and now even a massive triple-flue brick chimney in between.The case of the camera is very impressively hefty and rugged. I don't doubt that it is as weatherproof as the manufacturer claims. The IP66 rating is indeed impressive. It means that NO solid particles can enter the camera body. Period. There is no dust fine enough to get through the seals. It also means that no jet of water at any pressure from any direction can enter the camera enclosure. It might be susceptible to liquids only if completely submerged.Which leads me to the flaws:CONSAlthough the camera enclosure is impressively weatherproof, the electrical interface is not weatherproof at all, and it is permanently fixed to the camera through a singly hefty cable about a foot long. That cable ends in a receptacle for the Ethernet cable, which has two thinner cables about five inches long branching out the back, one to a connector for the power supply and the other to a small push-button reset switch. So any installation that takes advantage of the camera's ruggedness is going to have to provide separate and equal protection for those very vulnerable electronic connections, UNLESS you can bring the cable directly indoors within a foot of the camera. I can't do that, so I'm having to rig up another enclosure for them that will be mounted next to the camera. A little better attention to the design of the electronic interface would have made the camera's IP66 rating more easily exploited.The mounting bracket is one of the worst I have ever had the misfortune to wrestle with. I'm too angry at it right now to say much more, except that getting it adjusted and stable is a nightmare.The included software - as other reviewers have noted - is lame, as is most of the documentation (which completely ignores the mounting issues I just described). Clearly the manufacturer invested all its development budget in the camera itself, which at least was a wise choice. The camera really is so good that I still refuse to deduct even one star for these deficiencies.COMMENTSAfter a couple of hours' research, I followed another reviewer's lead and got Blue Iris software to control the camera. It is fantastic, and it's well worth the cost of $30 (support for one camera only) or $50 (up to 64 cameras). It makes setting up flawless motion detection, viewing video clips, zooming, panning (only in SW with this camera, but also in hardware with appropriate cameras), etc., a breeze. It has built-in support for this camera, and the only thing I haven't been able to do yet with it is adjust brightness and contrast, for which I had to use the included IPCamera Soft software. I did not have Blue Iris yet when I set up the camera's network interface through the Ethernet cable, so you may have to use the included software bundle to do that too. But that part is well enough documented and easy enough that it's okay.Finally: the color. Maybe color names have different meanings in China, but I never in a million years would have described this camera as "silver gray." It is a lovely lilac color, a definite, unmistakeable LILAC, without any hint of gray, although it IS a sort of silvery lilac. It is a beautiful color, but macho types will not be showing it off to their beer buddies.

Reviews.Title: decent camera, needs firmware update for mac compatibility
Reviews.Author: The Rocketdyke. "rocketdyke"
Reviews.Content: When first trying to access this camera, I was presented with a 320x240 image and no buttons in the interface. "strange," I thought, "shouldn't I have some kind of control over the camera features that other people talk about?"So instead of safari, I launched chrome. Same thing. Then firefox. Same thing. I cracked out User Agent Switcher in firefox and set it to be IE in windows 7. Presto! I had an interface, although most of the buttons were broken. Turns out they were doing some silly javascript OS sniffing, and dropping everyone in to the mobile device browser if they couldn't figure out what browser you were using.Thinking something was amiss, I contacted the seller. They suggested I download internet explorer for the mac. IE for mac? that hasn't been published since 2003 and won't run on an intel machine. Laughable. When I pointed this out to them, they asked me to contact them off amazon, as it stripped attachments, and they would send me a new firmware.So after a bit of email juggling, I get a new firmware file. Unfortunately, there is no way to upload it from a mac, so I booted up in my very old winXP that I keep handy and tried to install the "firmware" file they gave me. No good. Same problem when I rebooted into macOS. back to windows, and this time, I uploaded it in the "  Upgrade Device Embeded Web UI " box. This actually worked when I rebooted back to snow leopard. I now have full control over almost all of the camera features, but I cannot display a timestamp on the image, that appears to be a windows only setting.So, make sure you can get web UI version 0.0.4.18 from the vendor if you want to see this from a mac OS based browser. Also,  be prepared to use a dual-boot system to load the proper web ui firmware.Decent camera, decent images, I'll let people know if the weatherproofing doesn't hold up.but good luck if you only have a mac and can't dual-boot into windows.

Reviews.Title: Good camera/ Bad software
Reviews.Author: Matt Johnson
Reviews.Content: The Loftek Nexus 543 is a good all-around surveillance camera. It comes in a heavy duty, metal, outer shell with a descent quality camera. While you won't be able to make out face beyond 20' it will display activity with relative clarity.Wired setup for this IP camera was a breeze. Simply plug it in over your LAN and your monitoring program will find it. The wireless setup was a bit tricky. It will take a bit of playing around with before you get the settings right. You will need to plug the camera into a wired network to setup the wireless connection.The software that comes with this product is a joke. You can't mask areas you don't want monitored, the camera controls are horrible and it is difficult to navigate. I went with Blue Iris to record and monitor my system. My advice is to junk the software and use something that works.Overall I'm very happy with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Decent Build and Image Quality
Reviews.Author: EvaGrace
Reviews.Content: This low-cost IP camera is housed in an impressively heavy case. The outdoor rating means it can withstand jets of water, as well as extremely hot or cold tempuratures, and probably even the occasional rock or baseball that your neighbor's kids will throw at it.From my research and experience, the Nexus 543 has the same firmware and networking features as Loftek's CXS 2200 wireless pan-and-tilt camera, which I also own and frequently use. You can view the camera's live feed through most browsers and manually record live video to a PC on your network in MJPEG format. You can also view footage of your other IP cameras on the same interface.Although the web interface doesn't look very polished, it's easy to navigate. The camera supports DDNS, so you can assign its web interface to a standard URL for remote access, which is useful for users without a static IP address.The cam streams video at up to 640x480 resolution, and its saved images seem to be the same quality as stills from the MJPEG. Based on my experience, the Nexus 543 is a great security camera, with sturdy build quality and effective night vision.

Reviews.Title: Good image, poor software
Reviews.Author: S. Erholm "Scotty"
Reviews.Content: As others have mentioned, the setup software is not good. If you have a Windows machine, the setup is just amateurish.  If you use Mac or Linux, you likely need to know how to manipulate the settings on your router in order to configure the camera.The default IP for this cam is 192.168.0.178.  If the subnet of your router is also 192.168.0 then you can just use a Web browser to access the camera directly via the IP.  If your router is configured otherwise, you will need to be able to login to it and change the mask or the subnet.  Once you get the wired network for the camera set up as you wish (either via browser or poor Windows software), then you can access the camera and set many features.So set up can be painful, especially for non-Windows users, but then the camera works well.  The image quality surprised me for a cam of this price, and the IR LEDs actually work quite well to "see" in the dark up to about 30-40 feet (not as much as the claim of 25 meters).  The cam can upload images periodically to any server with FTP capabilities, or can also email them.  You can control the frequency of the uploads by specifying how many seconds.  Theoretically then, you could upload an image every second for real-time remote viewing, if your network connection is fast enough.  Every minute or five minutes is more realistic.Bottom line: If you need a really easy plug-n-play camera, spend a little more for a Panasonic with much better software.  If you need a really great image, then you need to spend 5 to 10 times more.  If you can deal with some setup issues and look past the really poor software, then the camera features, capabilities, and image quality are as good as cameras costing at least 2x as much.  Considering the price then, this is a great cam.

Reviews.Title: Thought this was a risky purchase. EXTREMELY happy I did.
Reviews.Author: arnaud lacour
Reviews.Content: First off, let me say this: I was afraid this would be a nightmare to install or wouldn't have the range allowing me to place the camera where I wanted it. Not so. It agreeably surprised me on both counts.It has built-in motion detection and upon detection will allow you to be notified by email, upload the picture to ftp and/or update an http of your choice.It allows for the default admin account to be changed (which some other do not which would be a major security issue for me) and connects to my router over WPA-TKIP.the ftp upload can also be configured on a regular basis, which is the feature I am using at the moment to feed sensr.net with recent captures.overall, this has worked right out of the box for me which I was very weary of but no, everything went as scripted.Do note that the CD coming with the camera has windows-only software on it so if you are a mac-only house (or shop), the only way you can make this work would be if your network is a 192.168.0, then you can hit [...] and hit the camera from there directly. In my case, my network is different and I had to use the excellent search tool provided, which found the camera and allowed me to make the camera available on my network.Overall just great!!!no complaints, I will buy 4 more to put under the eaves all around the house.

Reviews.Title: Very Capable IP Camera
Reviews.Author: sonyboy
Reviews.Content: Loftek's Nexus 543 wireless IP camera is compact and easy to use, even for non computer experts. It's got some handy features including automatic infrared illumination and inputs for external sensors and alarms, and for the price, it's hard to find a camera with the same performance.The Nexus 543 is useful if you want to use it with your existing wireless network, and is well-suited for monitoring a doorway, or for watching over a backyard or garage. If you want to place the camera far away from your router or hub, it might be a good idea to connect it using a LAN cable instead of using the wireless connection, which might not be able to span a long distance.A quick setup guide is included on the installation CD, as well as more detailed directions in the usual manual, and it also has included software which has more options than the browswer-based access that is standard. For example, you can view a ton of cameras (supposedly up to 60, if you're that kind of person). You can also record your footage and set up intervals for automatic recording and alarm settings, etc.Once you've installed the camera, you can access it over your wireless network, or you can mess around with your router settings if you want to watch it from another location. This takes a little bit of work, but is definitely worth it if you want to be able to see your camera while you're not at home. The camera's resolution of 640x480 has adequate video quality to identify people and vehicles, but there is no control for pan and tilt, so camera placement is quite important.The browser accessed video feed works in both Internet Explorer and Firefox, and has a slew of features that can be controled from here, of which the motion detection is especially useful. You can configure the camera to email you or upload shots to an FTP server when motion is detected in the user-specified area.Based on the features, appearance, and installation requirements, Loftek's Nexus 543 is a great outdoor camera that's easy to use and well-priced.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera For The Price
Reviews.Author: VABuyer
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research on cameras before I chose to buy this camera.  This is my first security camera and I didn't want to spend a lot of money.  I put this camera over my front door and it picks up good detail out to about 20-30 feet, even at night.  The picture is still good beyond that but there is some lose on clarity (face detail).  If I installed this in the eve of a house I don't think the picture detail would be as good at that height.The setup was quite simple and took about 20 minutes.  Just be sure to connect the camera to your router with a cable first.  A have a D-Link DIR-655 Xtreme N Gigabit Router and the camera connected wirelessly without a hitch.  I'm capturing the picture 640x480 and the speed is great.Overall, this is a great camera for the price and I will buy one for my back door when I get to that point.

Reviews.Title: Great picture for the Price!
Reviews.Author: Linda
Reviews.Content: The camera was easy to install and takes accurage recorded footage. I had to move my flag because itset it to record each time it waved in the view.  I may have to order another one to cover my entirefront yard.  I am very pleased with this product.

Reviews.Title: Good product for the price
Reviews.Author: Sonny
Reviews.Content: I've installed several cameras around my home and the LOFTEK seems to perform the best and most consistent. It's definitely made for outside use.

Reviews.Title: Initial thoughts
Reviews.Author: Riane Brownlee
Reviews.Content: Out of the box:-Big heavy unit and seems to be well constructed.-The installation CD was broken, but a quick Google search took me right to the Loftek website where the software can be downloaded.-The power cable is a little short, so be sure you have a way to supply power wherever you plan to mount.-The mounting bracket could stand to be a little more robust, but it should work for most applications.Installation:-Very straight-forward and relatively simple for basic intranet viewing.-The directions for remote viewing are rather clumsy. If you are tech savvy and know your way around network settings its easy, if you are not there are plenty of online how-to articles on setting this up.-I will not review the viewing software, I use a third party vendor software both for local and remote viewing.As things are now, I am very happy with this purchase. Now we wait to see how long it will last.

Reviews.Title: Not a bad camera, but not a good camera, sent it back
Reviews.Author: awsum140
Reviews.Content: We had some "comedians" that liked to off road through front yards in our neighborhood.  Rather than spike strips I decided on an IP camera.  After looking around at a few I settled on the 543.  Overall, for the money, at first it seemed like a pretty decent camera.  That changed in less than a month, though.The only reason I gave this "one star" is because I had to give it at least one to get the review posted.The mount is OK, but expect to use pliers to tighten things up enough to keep the camera from moving.  I have strong hands and still needed to use pliers to get the mount to hold solidly at the ball.  The housing is very substantial and looks to be totally weatherproof.  So far the camera has withstood several snow storms and some heavy rain as well.  The cable connections are not weatherproof and need to be inside a weather tight enclosure or even a plastic bag.The setup was a snap using an Ethernet cable into my hub.  Wireless connection also works quite nicely as long as you can stay in range.  Another problem is that the antenna is kind of "low end".  Mine broke on the first day when trying to position it properly to get a decent signal into the router.  I have replaced it with a high gain antenna and it does work OK but I am also going to run an Ethernet cable out to the camera to improve the frame rate.  The camera is about 125 feet from the router and I think if it were closer the wireless frame rate, bandwidth/connection speed, would be better.The daytime picture is quite good as long as there's not too much sunlight.  Once the bright sun hits its field of view it starts switching contrast/brightness with, apparently, the auto gain control in full saturation and unable to remain locked and stable.  This renders the camera useless in bright, daytime, conditions.  The camera faces north-northwest and "down" in my font yard so the sun is not getting directly onto the lens.  The night time picture quality is surprisingly good.  I'm not sure that the range is as great as advertised, but I would guess that at 50 feet you can make out a face from it.I can't say that I'm impressed with the support from Loftek.  According to the page I ordered from, the order is through Loftek and fulfilled by Amazon.  I have sent a total of four questions to Loftek and haven't received an answer to any of them, yet, and it's been over a month.  That is not very encouraging.The software for monitoring the camera is kind of basic.  It may work OK for some people, but I wanted more flexibility and purchased Blue Iris.  I am not interested in viewing the camera from outside of my local network, but I think port forwarding could be setup fairly easily.I have emailed Loftek a total of four times asking questions about the camera, from a software/browser problem I solved myself, to a problem with the brightness of the picture changing in bright sunlight at about a 1 second rate.  I have yet to receive the courtesy of a reply after a month.  If you want an IP camera, look elsewhere, Loftek DOES NOT SUPPORT THEIR OWN PRODUCT!I've had it with this camera.  For the price, it seemed a good trade off of quality and price, but the support, no support, from Loftek and the constant flashing in brightness/contrast during times of bright sunlight have rendered it basically useless.  Amazon was nice enough to offer a full refund when I contacted them regarding the failure of the camera and Loftek.  Personally, I will not be ordering any more Loftek cameras.  There are far better ones out there.

Reviews.Title: Good value for money.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as it was wireless. It works and not too many problems setting it up once I discovered IE compatibility view was necessary! The picture is good, even in low light. Moreover, it is Well designed, looks well built and it has survived the storm so far.I must say at a cost of $74.99 it is good!

Reviews.Title: Breaking after a few months
Reviews.Author: FearTheSwamp
Reviews.Content: Setup was clunky. Black spots started showing up after a few months. Only have the screen is visible now.  May try again.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Buy!
Reviews.Author: Brooke Hamilton "gossip"
Reviews.Content: I have been looking for a weatherproof wireless camera for a long time and did a large amount of research and decided to purchase Loftek camera, due to the great reviews and multiple videos on  [...] and Facebook. I was not disappointed when I tried this product.I used the camera to monitor my garden. The Loftek Nexus 543 comes with IR Cut, so I got wonderful image in the day time. And wireless works very well, i can monitor my garden with ipad when I lounge in my bedroom. Very good camera, highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Setting up was a nightmare but great support conquered it.
Reviews.Author: Jake Darby
Reviews.Content: Firstly, I must say that it’s not easy for people who don’t quite understand how to set up a router. I am the people. I tried it several times and it all turned out fail. At the very start, I thought I can totally fix this out in one hand. I was wrong. Then I contacted their customer service and got the great support. I have sent 4 letters in total and all the emails got the timely reply.The problem I asked includes: 1) how to set up wireless;2) how to set up the port forward;3) how to use the app to watch the picture.All the problems have been described in details. I thought that it’s quite important for the people who want to buy. Because not all the people know how to set it right. After that, I used it with satisfaction. The IR works great. The night version is good and can see things clear in the dark. I used it to keep eyes on the furniture and some exercise machines in my garden. Once I set up the port forward and downloaded the app IPCloud, I can see the real-time picture on my iphone. And that’s quite a charm. The only flaw of this stationary camera is that the angle is not very wide. If you need to monitor spacious place, I will suggest you to buy more of it or to buy camera with wide angle.Overall, it’s brilliant.

Reviews.Title: Works well!
Reviews.Author: Diana L
Reviews.Content: This is our first outdoor IP cam.  Due to changes in the neighborhood we wanted a cam to be able to check on things when we are away and also  to be able to do a quick check outside when home (day and evening).I read the reviews (including the negative ones) but the price outweighed any negative reviews.The package arrived fast and in good condition.  The shell is  very sturdy and solid.  We needed something weatherproof as we deal with a lot of lake effect snow (we live near Chicago)- and this cam really impressed us.  The install was fast and easy- I was impressed with how easy it was to do.  My husband had it installed before I realized he was even working on  it.  Plus- it blends in very nicely in the eaves of the roof so  it isn't obvious.This camera fit all our needs. I feel much more safe if my husband has to work late.  Our insurance agent was also happy to hear we had installed the cam.  I don't know if it helps with insurance costs but it sure helps with peace of mind. The images look sharp and the night vision is good.  I am very glad my husband and I ordered this cam and we plan on ordering a few more to place around the house and also on the garage.

Reviews.Title: So far so good!
Reviews.Author: bitOhoney535
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera because of its wireless function. Really fast shipment and the package well. No problem on wired setting but at a loss on how to connect it to my router wirelessly-The camera can’t search any networks at all. I connected to LOFTEK and they helped me to set up the camera. After reset it and changed some setting of my TP-Link wireless router, I finally got the camera work via wireless and everything work well so far. 4 points for the camera itself, 1 point for customer service, 5 points deserved!

Reviews.Title: Decent Outdoor Camera!
Reviews.Author: Beth
Reviews.Content: I purchased several weatherproof wireless cameras including Foscam and Loftek cameras for my home security system. I set up two FI8905 and one FI8904 for nearly three months, one of FI8905 dropped frames in the third month and the other the night version stopped working so I returned them and ordered two Loftek Nexus 543 instead. I found Loftek Nexus virtually has the same functionalities as Foscam FI8905. They both use 4mm lens, support motion detection alerts to email and are FTP, wireless and remote enabled. Loftek Nexus 543 seems have a more stable image and quality. And it has a much lower price than FI8904. The two Nexus have already worked for about half a year and still have a very sharp picture. The only drawback was that it was a little bit hard to set up on Mac but it wasn't be a problem for me. I give it 4 stars for its performance.

Reviews.Title: Loftek 543 with Zoneminder
Reviews.Author: Hambodian
Reviews.Content: Running 3 of these wirelessly on a dedicated wireless router, old Dell server with ubuntu server and Zoneminder. Works better than I expected.  Been running 24/7 for a few months now on continuous record

Reviews.Title: In expensive WiFi solution!
Reviews.Author: Scott Kessler "Sussco"
Reviews.Content: I have used several of these type cameras from different manufacturers, this on is by far the very best i have found. The price is the lowest and the software and WiFi are the best, my last one would loose connectivity with my security software from time to time and i blamed it on my WiFi network i found out that it was the camera this cam works flawlessly and has a great picture!The distributor sent this out quickly and was packaged well!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the money
Reviews.Author: Burt Gummer
Reviews.Content: This is my first security camera, I bought this one to record anything that comes up my driveway.  Getting the camera up and running on my wifi was just a matter of following the enclosed instructions......it took about 5 minutes.  Installation outside does require a power outlet, so if you can handle wiring in an outlet where you want to install the camera it is not a problem. Get a weatherproof enclosure for your outlet and simply install right next to where you want the camera.  I was able to stuff pigtail from the camera into the enclosure along with the power adapter.  As for the performance I was pleasantly surprised at the quality both night and day as it was very clear and the IR works out to a 30 plus yards.  I set the camera up to motion alarm and e-mail pictures so that when I'm gone I can see who approached the house.  Overall I'd have to give this camera 5 stars and I think I'll install a couple more.

Reviews.Title: Great IP Camera!
Reviews.Author: Robert
Reviews.Content: Camera works well outside or inside. IR performance is very good and illuminates out to a far distance. Setup was easy (but I also have experience with IP Cameras). The included mounting hardware worked well for me. I would recommend this camera to another person.

Reviews.Title: Wrong Power Supply AND Camera Won't Boot
Reviews.Author: W. Joe
Reviews.Content: I already have several Loftek Nexus 543 cameras and I've had good experiences with all of them.  However, I can't say the same for the one I just purchased.First, the 5v power supply comes with the wrong size tip making the camera unusable.  Based on a comment in another review that reported the same problem, I tried a power supply from one of my other cameras only to find that it would not boot even though I can hear the camera boot / reset when the power is first connected.I'm hopeful the seller will be able to provide a working unit.UPDATE - UPDATE - UPDATE - UPDATEThe seller eventually sent me a replacement camera after I returned the defective one.  Much to my surprise, the replacement camera also had the wrong power supply in the box.As with the other camera, I tried a power supply from a working camera and I can hear the camera boot and I can even hear it switch between day and night modes - BUT I NEVER GET AN ETHERNET NETWORK LINK LIGHT.  So, with no network connectivity this camera is basically a brick.This sounds to be the same issue that others are having.  Just look at the comments in chronological order.I'm extremely disappointed that they shipped me a camera with the wrong power supply AGAIN after my explicit request to either send me one that has been tested or to refund my money.So far this has been the WORST experience I've ever had with any Amazon purchase.  As much as I like my older Loftek cameras, I won't be purchasing any more...With that said, I would welcome any recommendations on a camera with similar features that actually comes with the right power supply and works as advertised.

Reviews.Title: Good optical package; software is not for the technically timid...
Reviews.Author: 35-year Technology Consumer "8-tracks to 802.11"
Reviews.Content: This camera must be considered as two parts: the video hardware and the controlling software. This is a review that really needs to be 3.5 stars, but without that option and with some major usability challenges and browser dependencies, three stars it is.Overall, the camera is physically robust. In fact, I dropped it while placing it in its final operational location (from three feet onto a tile floor), and it passed this unintentional test with flying colors. Read the specs: it's large, so is clearly best for outdoor or voluminous indoor spaces. It will be rather awkward if placed in sight in most residential-scale places.Color and clarity are fine, and switching between visible and IR are instantaneous and problem free.The drawbacks of this camera come from its controlling software. In short, users can expect a four-part process:(1) assign internal IP address (wired).(2) set up video control.(3) configure internal wireless settings.(4) configure remote access wireless settings.Although the wireless features will work with Firefox and Chrome, they are optimized for Internet Explorer. So even though this is an IP-based camera, don't expect it to be Unix-friendly.None of these are for the technologically faint of heart. You MUST be comfortable with internal IP address configuration options (in both the camera software and your router). This camera's configuration is controlled through two separate programs, and has to be done in sequence. Initial set up begins with a wired ethernet connection and then moves to wireless options.Once configured (in either wireless or wired modes), the camera is enabled with options for either scheduled or motion detection recordings. I now enjoy audible alarms whenever the cat approaches his food dish.The unit ships with an adequate quick start guide. A longer user guide is included on the accompanying CD as a Word document. One of the understandable challenges this vendor faced is that they couldn't possibly be successful in providing settings for every router potentially being operated by all users. If you feel like the user guide doesn't give instructions that address your router's interface closely enough, you can find assistance online (both at youtube and portforwarding dot com). While I am not a programmer, I am certain that some of the initial configuration could be automated on the installation CD to create a better out of the box experience.Finally, although the camera body may be weatherproof,  the combined ethernet/DC power dongle and the wall wart AC adapter don't appear especially robust, so you'll have to make provisions for their protection. Obviously, placement will be dependent on availability of an AC power outlet or extension cord.Note: I received this item at no charge.

Reviews.Title: Not suited for outdoor use, but good support
Reviews.Author: ecellingsworth
Reviews.Content: Edit 3/31/14: The replacement camera I received after one had filled with rain is now dead. We had an exceptionally cold winter for the southern United States. Problems started around the beginning of winter with the camera disappearing from the network occasionally. Near mid-winter the camera was MIA about 50% of the time. I noticed it would be working during the daylight hours when it was warm but would stop responding around midnight when the cold would set in. Now, with winter over, the camera no longer responds at all. I haven't taken the time to determine if the problem is the power supply or the camera. I'm hoping it's the former. I still have one camera working (for 2 years now) under a patio roof that has never had problems. Even so, I can't recommend these for outside use. I've changed the title of my review from "Not weather proof, but good support" to "Not suited for outdoor use, but good support". I've changed my star rating from 4/5 to 2/5 since I've had two cameras die in 2 years.The original review is below.I have two of these cameras installed outside. The first is mounted under the patio roof and is working well. However, this location seems to block WiFi. I installed a second wireless access point close by, but it didn't help. When I swap the other camera to this position, it has the same problem, but works fine elsewhere. Therefore, I ran an ethernet cable directly to this camera - problem solved. This camera has been on continuously for about 3 months. The image has developed a small blemish. I thought it was dirt but cleaning the lens didn't help. I'm still not sure if this is from the camera itself, but it doesn't really affect anything.The second camera was originally installed on the exterior of the house, directly exposed to the weather. WiFi worked fine in this location, but after ~ 2 months the camera picture started going in and out until it was barely ever on. I inspected the camera and found it had filled inside with water from recent rain showers. I emailed Loftek's support and was asked to take a photo of the defective camera which I did. Without any further questions I was given an RMA number and asked to mail the camera to some place in California. Once the camera arrived, they immediately shipped me a replacement (new) that I've since reinstalled under an overhang in the same location. It's working fine now for a week. My positive experience returning the defective camera is what prompted me to write this review. Even with one water-logged camera, I would feel confident buying from this company again.Here's a summary of my opinions:1. Customer support = 10/10. Quick and courteous. Search the reviews and you'll see they even leave comments. This is a company that cares about how it is perceived.2. Weather proof = 5/10. Should be fine in a covered location. Definitely keep out of the rain, etc.3. Picture quality = 8/10. Really, it's what you'd expect for 640x480 resolution. Colors are adequate.4. Night vision = 9/10. IR LED's won't cover your whole yard, but work great in small spaces. IR filter is a plus.5. WiFi = 7/10. Works, but really depends on shielding and noise sources around the camera. For dependable connection, I highly recommend hardwiring IP cameras.6. Aesthetics = 10/10. Looks imposing to criminals.7. Software setup = 8/10. I had no trouble. The last one took me all of 5 minutes to configure. It helps to have some networking experience though.8. Motion detection = 9/10. Simple and effective. Emails me 5 frames at each event. Detection works better than Zoneminder, in my opinion. However, I've noticed that during motion events, third party recording software (Zoneminder) is denied frames, which is a shame. Best to use one or the other, not both at the same time.9. Durability = 10/10. Metal body feels firm. No mechanical problems to date.10. Features = 9/10. Has a lot of configuration options. I didn't give it 10/10 because there's no built-in way to disable the manufacturers DDNS service (though Loftek has a program on it's site that can do this). And, there is only a few 3rd party DDNS service providers in the pre-programmed list and no way to add more, which is a little restrictive.

Reviews.Title: Well made camera.  Nice software.  Mount sucks.
Reviews.Author: Ed
Reviews.Content: The camera is very well made out of extruded aluminum with high quality parts and components.  The mount provides no way for the camera to be screwed or mounted to your wall without adaption.  The mount has a 5/16th inch threaded bolt which can be put through a hole in a bracket and screwed tight.  The manual sucks.  the software seems pretty nice and works as designed so far.  It was not hard to setup but you should change the default password and user names "admin" and 1"23456" for the Password.  Well worth the $89 price for a prime member. I will have to update you after the first rain/snow to see if it still performs outside.

Reviews.Title: Bad Bracket, limited support
Reviews.Author: Scott
Reviews.Content: be careful using the mounting bracket.  The first time I screwed it into the camera it broke off in the camera rendering it useless.  I did not screw it in tightly, it just was a cheap aluminum bracket that broke.  very disappointing. The camera itself is OK, not too difficult to set up, but seems to have limited support among IP Camera software products, for example Blue Iris.  You can access it over the internet using the software provided by the camera, but so far I have not found any software that supports Loftek Nexus 543 cameras to consolidate it with my other cameras.  Seems to have some sort of unique way of logging into the camera.

Reviews.Title: Loftek is a winner
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: After purchasing two Nexus 543 cameras I had trouble with one of them. I don't know if it was misdirected "E" mails or what? I gave them a bad review and that got the ball rolling. They went out of there way to get me a new camera. Now both cameras have been trouble free and a good value for the money. Thanks Loftek

Reviews.Title: wont work
Reviews.Author: jim
Reviews.Content: The dcph client dose not work on the cam also the ''wireless'' only works a few feet away but if you get one that works the picture is great.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Product, Excellent Supprot
Reviews.Author: D. Osborne
Reviews.Content: After reviewing a number of similar outdoor IP camera products, I selected the Loftek camera from numerous good reviews, price comparison and the statement that Loftek would support it when purchased from Amazon (not something every company stated).  The camera arrived as expected, worked as expected, was easy to setup on my network and Internet even without the included CD, and installed as desired.  I am not using wireless, hardwired only.  The only negative is the length of cable connections, could be longer.The only problem came after finding the coverage area slightly out of focus.  Loftek Tech Support responded quickly to an e-mail and further investigation found the focal center and depth to be shorter than expected, about 20 ft plus or minus 10ft and dependent on area illumination (brightness), but still very much usable.  Further investigation found the focus and depth on a fixed lens, fixed aperture will vary slightly with brightness. Loftek did provide refocusing instructions, but I decided to leave well enough alone.  Loftek also provides an software API, which allows interfacing to existing web and server applications.  I will be buying more of these in the near future.

Reviews.Title: Newer Units different color and different bracket. IMPROVED
Reviews.Author: dcohn
Reviews.Content: Bought 3 cameras. One in dec 2011, One March 4, 2012 and one more today.Very easy to setup and mount and install.  Cake actually.  Issue we have is the first unit is a Purplish Dark Grey color with a very cheap bracket.  The newer unit is a more ALUMINUM SILVER color with a nice strong bracket to mount it with and better firmware it seems.Having an issue with first unit wireless connections. It works but need to work out issue with tech support.  No question the newer version is a better product.Gave 4 stars in hope tech support does right by me.  I expect they will.All units purchased direct from Loftek.  All say Loftek on them.Will return to update

Reviews.Title: bracket and screws rusted out in 3 months of outdoor use
Reviews.Author: E. Chiu "Jayson's Dad"
Reviews.Content: It claimed to be an "outdoor" camera but the bracket and screws rusted out in 3 months of outdoor use. Other than this, everything worked as expected.

Reviews.Title: Installed today.  Works perfectly so far.
Reviews.Author: Don "Don"
Reviews.Content: This camera works good for me so far. I got it today and installed it and if it keeps working like it is now it is perfect.

Reviews.Title: Cannot change the host name or backup camera settings
Reviews.Author: C. Genovese
Reviews.Content: I have bought both the 2200 the 3200 and the 543 outdoor camera from Loftek.  You cannot change the host name on the cameras.  So when I have these setup for alarm when I get my text message for motion it gives me some random letters and numbers as the host name.  I can change the hostnames on my Foscam however.  Also If you want to configure a bunch of these cameras you have to setup each camera instead of being able to load a file onto the camera with all your settings.  Loftek has superior hardware to Foscam but the software in my opinion has flaws.  Also be very careful with the mounting screws where they enter the case.  If you try to change the screw out for a longer one you can puncture the IC chip on the board.  look through the hole in the bottom of the camera enclosure and you will see.

Reviews.Title: Great value, outstanding night vision
Reviews.Author: Andrew Weinberg "Savvy and smart"
Reviews.Content: I read all the reviews and can only say things have gotten better. I received the cams 3 weeks ago and put them through some serious burn in time. I tested Mac, PC, and linux.1) The browser interface works well with all functions capable on all platforms, including recording, motion detection, email alerts, and multiple camera control through a single browser session.2) Set up was easy3) The IP cam software included (PC only) is very basic and slow. No need to even use it as the browser handles it all in a better fashion. (see the advanced, multi device area for monitoring multiple cameras in one session). Would be 5 stars if the software included on CD was better.4) Loftek IS a china based company, sp those stating they have seen chinese versions, you are seeing rebranded Loftek cameras. Support does respond, but in Beijing time, meaning 9pm-10am U.S time. the do respond and follow up, which was very nice.Overall for the price point this is a great deal. I have set up many a security systems and these cams offer a good middle of the road solution without breaking your bank. Video quality is fair...good enough for surveillance, which is what they are for. If you want HD video, buy a Video cam and not a security cam.

Reviews.Title: Good Network Camera - Will Need different software for Mac
Reviews.Author: Ricky Dicky
Reviews.Content: I purchased two of these cameras, one for the front door and one for the backdoor. Setting these network cameras was as simple as 1-2-3-4. If you want easy to understand instructions that will get you up and running wirelessly fast you should go to Loftek's website and select the 543 model. At their website you can download/view easy to understand instructions that will take you step by step. It took me less than 10 minutes to set both of these cameras up wirelessly. You will need a PC or windows running on your Mac to first setup the network cameras. Once you have set the cameras set up on your local network you will need different software if you want to use your MAC to record content from the Loftek cameras. I scoured the net for "ip camera software for Mac" and came up with the wonderful MAC program called EvoCam. The program is free to download and gives you 15 days of full use for free, after 15 days you will have to purchase it. The program only cost me $20 with a student discount, otherwise it's $30. Although the Loftek camera is not listed as one of the network cameras on this program I found that you can use the " Foscam Network Camera (1)" setting and it will work like a charm. You can set a recording schedule for your cameras. You will need to customize a window for each camera on the EvoCam software. I recommend setting up a folder for each camera.Installing the camera: You HAVE to use the included 5v ac adapter to power the camera. You will need to splice off of an outdoor power source such as an outdoor light. I spliced off of my front door light and my backdoor light. Buy a small outdoor electrical box at a place like Lowe's and buy a small female plug receptacle. Wire the positive and negative terminal on the female plug receptacle and connect the positive and negative wire to the positive and negative wire at the outdoor wiring (outdoor light source wiring in back of outdoor light). Drill a hole at the bottom of the small electrical box that will allow the wiring to pass through the electrical box. The small electrical box will house the adapter and plug receptacle. Plug the adapter into the female plug receptacle and run the wiring through the hole at the bottom of the electrical box. Screw the cover back on the small electrical box affix teh electrical on your house near where you want to install the camera. Install the camera. BEFORE you mess with the electrical wiring turn the power off at your fuse box so you don't get electrocuted.Camera quality: The infrared night-vision works nice and is clear. These cameras have pretty good resolution. You get 30 fps (frames per second) with this camera which is pretty good. I like the cameras so far and they seem to be weatherproof as advertised. I've had them up and running for about a week, so far so good. I really like the EvoCam software for my Mac. My Imac works perfect with this software, I run it 24 hrs a day and my Imac is so quiet you can hear a pin drop. If you are using an IMAC make sure that you have your setting so that the hard drive doesn't cut off (energy saver mode) and doesn't go to sleep. Your display can cut off but not your computer, NO SLEEP MODE. Go to APPLE>SYSTEM Perferences>Energy Save>Computer Sleep --> slide to "Never". Uncheck the "put Hard drive to sleep" box if it is checked. If you don't do this you will wake up to frozen EvoCam windows that show searching. If you get a freeze you will have to go to your username and then the library folder and then delete the "com.evocam" file to reset it and then you will have to redo all of your settings all over again and add the network camera settings again. I recommend getting a backup power source b/c any interruption in power will make you have to reset the program and redo all of the settings again.

Reviews.Title: I'd buy it again
Reviews.Author: Karl Kuzbiel
Reviews.Content: Looks like this is a generic China-made camera. I've seen the exact same camera under different names. However, I am pretty happy with the purchase. This is my first IP camera and I thought the image quality is mediocre but I saw clips from more higher-end ($400) cameras and those aren't too much better.Good-wireless works well for me-image quality-price-ease of useBad-software

Reviews.Title: Wireless feature doesn't work
Reviews.Author: Angela Clark
Reviews.Content: It is not a bad camera for this amount of money, considering it is rated as an outdoor + has a night vision. Read the description and realize that you're getting exactly what you're paying for, no need to be disappointed because it is not wide angle or the image quality is not that high. Unfortunately, I never had a chance to test how sturdy it is because wireless feature never worked. I think the unit I received was defective because when I tried to use "scan" button, which supposedly should find all wireless networks transmitting the signal, nothing happened. I tried several times, but this camera would not find a single network (when I had several). I also tried to enter my SSID, security type and password manually, but camera would not connect to the network.There are no phone numbers to contact Loftek technical support. I wrote them an email more than a week ago describing the problem and haven't received a reply.Buy only if you don't need wireless function or if you're willing to take a risk. Also, use 3d party monitoring software, e.g. Blue Iris since Loftek's software is very basic.Apparently, I am not the only one who got this camera with non-working WiFi. Amazon has very nice return policy, which I will utilize in this case.

Reviews.Title: Can't get wireless to work on my network
Reviews.Author: Wullow Still
Reviews.Content: I have a 2wire router. It has no trouble when I hook up the cam via Ethernet, but no matter what I tinker with, the router just cannot see the cam when it's wireless. Documentation is crappy, just like the configuration UI (e.g., you can set motion detector "sensibility"). Support is only by email, and no one works nights or weekends. Support had me try various things that directly contradict their video and documentation.Update: Seller gave me a refund with no hassle.

Reviews.Title: Loftek Nexus 543
Reviews.Author: Fastone01
Reviews.Content: I am looking to replace my 4 year old aging Wilife (Logitech brand)camera system with a Network IP wireless camera system. Started looking about a month ago, reading reviews on what new offering out there that is available. Reason I want to replace is that one of the unit outdoor is dead, the other one indoor is still functional, the 2nd reason, Wilife system does not have night vision.Decide to give the loftek brand a try. I ordered 2 of these November 24 and got it 5 days later.As everyone knows, the documentation is pretty spotty, but once you go thru the CD and manuals, you can pretty much puzzle the documentation together and go forth what you really need to do.You have to connect the camera WIRED during initial setup, and use the utility that came with called > BSearch_en.exe to configure cameras IP address of your network, username/pass(default info on documentation or sticker in the body of the camera), and PORT you want to use BESIDES 80 or 8080 to get it to connect.Wireless function, go to the Network configuration > Wireless tab and put the information of your network wireless to detect.If your wireless SSID is hidden, temporarily unhide it to assist the camera to find your wirelessOnce configured power off camera and disconnect the RJ45 wired connection. Power on, wait 10 to15 seconds for it to switch to wireless function. Once wireless is up, you can finish off configuring the rest.One of the 2 cameras I originally ordered will not work with the wireless. After careful observation, the gold connector where the wireless antenna connects to the camera body is not there. End up returning this unit. There is no exchange option with seller, once Amazon got the defective camera, immediate full amount refund + return shipping cost amount. Nice!Immediately order the 2nd  replacement camera.Moving forwardWhile waiting for the other replacement to come, I finish configuring the first camera.CAN NOT get the included software called > IPCmonitor to work.I tried installing on 6 different computers with OS, XP, vista, W7 x32 /X64, 2k3 or 2K8 x32 /X64 versions. NADA!Work with technical support (only email support) for 3 days, email tags back and forth but never really connected with them as they wanted to connect to my computer using TeamViewer remote due to time zone difference with emails. There technical support must be outside the USAI end up buying BlueIris multi-view version and got it to work.The camera also works remote view on my blackberry and IPAD outside my network to monitor using the browser function.Email, took some time to trace why not sending but it end up a combo issue of firewall and anti-virus software blocking SMTP broadcast.Initial impression of first camera, for a 640x480, pix and video are clear day time, night vision is also clear.End up using WIRED connection versus wireless as I did not want to move my wireless router location which is located the other side corner of my house. It will work but want the steady connection of 15 -18 FPS versus 5 - 2 FPS on wireless. Note: 2 cameras together wired, FPS goes down to 10-12 FPSAfter 4 days of using the first camera, I notice from comparison with original video and pix captured that the camera pix quality now has deteriorated somewhat. Just thought it might be just the weather.Another is I am getting alerts that the camera resets 2 to 4 times at night. No biggy, the BlueIris software attempts to restarts the camera and it does.The 2nd replacement camera finally came and was configured. All is working. Once up, the initial impression was WOW, this one has a nice pix and video. The colors are true Green and grass is not brown, the images are sharp and clear. It made me think that the first camera has some issues with contrast and Brightness, so I mess with the first camera setting to equal the setting of the 2nd replacement camera. Close but not quite there.Now, the 2nd replacement camera at night. Low light with just the porch light by the driveway is ON, IR is OFF on camera,  I CAN NOT see anything except small dot where light is reflected back like signal light reflectors off your car.NO LIGHTS ON driveway, IR is ON the Camera, it looks like I am looking at a barrel of shotgun or being time warp to another universe! The pix and video, there is a HALO view around the corners, pix and video is warped/distorted with 6 white dot spot around it. I can't get to recognition images off this!Decided to mess with the brightness and contrast as well for night time, but the HALO effect is still there. Original thought is that the IR LED reflection when ON might be bouncing off the shiny hood of the camera. I decided to put electrical black tape on the inside part of the hood, maybe it that what causing the warp/distorted with 6 white dot reflection on this camera. Nope, the same!Next day, since I started messing around with the contrast/brightness setting on both cameras the night before, Day time setting now looks washout on the replacement camera, the original camera, I now have a 3D images of pix and video. It looks like 3D vision on a LCD panel looking at it without the 3D glasses.It gives me a headache!Oh geez, could it be that I am spacing out! Not! I open up my old original 4 year old Wilife camera system and oh boy, these 2 new cameras do not even come close to the pix/video quality.Decided to give both loftek cameras another try by resetting both to Factory defaults, and move them back inside to my warm computer room for further evaluation.Results are the same.Original camera now has a 3D image effect day or night and progressively getting worse2nd replacement camera, pix are great in daytime but at night IR ON, Halo and 6 white dots present no matter what I do. By the way, both cameras are on the latest and greatest firmware update.Also, it is not the BlueIris software causing this because when I use the original viewing software from loftek, same issue and the output for pix and video is even worse.Both cameras are returned back to Amazon My opinion is that the CAMERA QUALITY control is not there. Most of these cameras probably came from the same one or 2 manufacturers. Some people reviews states that there camera works great for a while and other not. For the amount you are paying for this unit, you have a 50/50 chance on the deal so give it a try.End up getting an EasyN and a Vivotek outdoor models using blue Iris. Waiting for them come in the mail to be tested and configured. Both cameras are a lot more dollars but my main objective is to get clear view at night and products that will work after the manufacture warranty expires like my old system.

Reviews.Content: I own this and three Foscam cameras, two PTZ F18918 and one outdoor camera F18904.  The Loftek camera is terrible.  The image if fuzzy and now that the weather is getting cooler, the camera image is totally worthless.  The Foscam F18904 is working flawlessly in the cooler temperatures but the Loftek is unusable.  The software was much less functional than the Foscam software.  I am going to order another Foscam outdoor camera to replace the Loftek.  The Loftek is garbage.

Reviews.Title: Not very wireless
Reviews.Author: M. Joreski
Reviews.Content: The camera its self is nice and so far water resistant. Now for the bad news. Wireless is pretty much useless. Even indoors with the camera 5 feet from my router (Netgear WNDR3700) the frame rate would peek at 5 fps at (648X480) with the antenna on the camera in a perfect position. Move the camera away from the router and the frame rate falls to .5 fps. I spent over 30 hours trying different configurations, moving other wireless equipment, changing position of the antenna, trying every channel available, and moving the base router with just 1 wall in between it and the camera. I feel I am fairly good at solving problems with my network but I gave up on the wireless and hard wired it to the router. Believe it or not with the camera hardwired to the router and the best frame rate I can get is 10 fps. It is usable but far from a good security camera. Oh and before I forget there is not much color in the color camera, the picture is mostly black and white.

Reviews.Title: good product and good customer service
Reviews.Author: James R Beaty
Reviews.Content: Give it a 5 because the product is good and the customer service is solid.  I got the camera installed with minimal problems and it works well in an application where I monitor side yard activity particularly at night. My monitoring distance is 60-70 feet and the image is good and clear.  I was not able to figure out how to capture footage when the camera is triggered so I purchased Blue Iris software which does a great job doing that.  The camera triggers off of motion so it is a bit sensitive on windy nights but there are filters that help to minimize the false triggers. I wouldn't have this problem if I wasn't trying to monitor a heavily treed area. The camera ran for three months non-stop and then stopped working.  I worked with Loftek technical service for a week but we couldn't get the camera to respond to the things we tried.  The technical service is via email communication so it takes some patience but they respond very timely. At one point the technician wanted to go live on my computer and due to the warnings from Microsoft when I tried to import the communication software, I declined to have the tech enter my machine. I finally asked that they send me a replacement camera and they did. When it arrived I had it installed in an hour and back in business. Based on my experience with the camera and the responsiveness of Loftek this product deserves 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Great quality affordable IP Camera
Reviews.Author: White-Out Reviews "White-Out Reviews"
Reviews.Content: This is a wired/wireless IP surveillance camera. This is a great, affordable security solution for your home or business.The Nexus 543 has a long body and is slightly larger than other IP surveillance camera's. It's not too large and has a silver sleek look. The Nexus 543 comes with an antenna for the wireless users and an Ethernet jack for a hard wired connection. I prefer to use the wireless option as it optimizes the locations of my cameras.Once you open up the box, attach the wireless antenna, power it on and hook in an Ethernet cable to your router, it's time for setup. Definitely read the instructions carefully, as you need to setup the wireless IP address separate from the wired IP address. The instructions are very easy to read and the install of the given software was quick. Once you have gone through the instructions and you have setup your wireless IP address, you can disconnect the Ethernet cable and place the IP camera where it's needed.The Nexus 543 is a stationary IP camera and lacks the controls for camera movement. I have mine setup in a corner and the camera is able to capture the entire room, therefore not having a need to move the camera.The camera features 36 infrared LED's for optimizing clarity in the dark and also benefits from having an IP66 waterproof rating for outdoor usage. The Nexus 543 gives a few options of video quality for different user preferences and consists of VGA,QVGA, QQVGA and MJPEG. This is great to have if you have slower network speeds with your router or switch. The antenna uses an 802.11B/G standard and I think that needs to be improved to N.The software features how to remote into the camera, change the video settings and capture speeds as well as setup to be controlled by almost any smartphone. You can also use any major browser to remote into the camera as well. I prefer Google's Chrome as it seems to run smoother with the needed plugins.I really enjoyed using the Nexus 543 and it fits in perfectly with my other IP cameras.

Reviews.Title: Fair quality, unacceptable technical support
Reviews.Author: Guajiro
Reviews.Content: The camera seems to be sturdy (rain to come yet!). The quality of the video is not too bad within about 15 feet. Fairly good at night. My requirement for this unit is very limited so it is acceptable, although I thought seriously about returning it. Here are the issues I see with it (keep in mind I am well versed in networks and computers and have lots of time in my hands):* Not easy to set up because the Manual is practically useless* Software seems buggy and outdated.* Technical support is only via e-mail. Sometimes it takes several days for an answer (never on weekends), so it may take you a week or more to fix an issue. When the e-mail arrives you still have to figure what to do with the information, which is usually in broken English. I have owned the camera shy of a month and have spent probably 3-4 hours daily in trying to get it to work. If you do not have that kind of time and knowledge, do not purchase it.* As of yet I haven't been able to set up remote viewing through the WAN. AFT is useless trying to set it up. Fortunately I do not need it. It will take a snapshot and send it to you via e-mail. The feature works very well, and you get dozens of e-mail because it snaps pictures all day and night long! You need, trough trial and error, to discover what is the best sensitivity level and FPS. Again, the manual and the support do not come thru on this. The "support person" will answer you sooner or later but eventually you will be asked to send them a password so they can remotely help you (I believe they are in China). I don't know about you, but I am not comfortable letting someone get into my computer, so I turned that offer down and stopped communicating with them. I can live with the unit, as limited as it is. Had the support been better, I would have probably rated the unit at least a 3 or 4.

Reviews.Title: Useless for Security Monitoring
Reviews.Author: GrainneX
Reviews.Content: I don't have much time to write; so, I'll cover the basics.  I've submitted a support request to Loftek.  If they answer and solve the problem, I'll update this post.Mounting Bracket : USELESS.  The cast metal is brittle and hard to tighten loosen.  I broke the threaded shaft into the camera when screwing it in.  Literally, a young child could break these things.Image Quality : Pretty decent.Setup : Requires windows.  Yeah!  So, if you have Macs only, you'll need a friend to assist.  After that, you can use and view on a Mac. Overall, the software is decent enough to work with.Wiring : I don't think camera designers have ever installed a camera.  What do you do with a useless 1 foot long donge that is HUGE?  Ever tried to install a camera under the eaves of a house?  That one foot dongle means you have to crawl through insulation to the very edge of the roof and try one handed to connect the power cord to the dongle.SHOW STOPPER : This camera is useless for security monitoring.  I have one of these cameras pointed at my mailbox / driveway.  I have motion sensitivity at the highest setting. While watching the camera "live", it perfectly shows cars going by, me walking to the mailbox, etc.  However, it records just ONE of the images and sends via FTP.  If a car comes down my long driveway, it USUALLY records a single image.  Sometimes, it records NONE.  If a car drives by at 20 mph, it sends no pictures.  So, if you MIGHT want to catch a criminal, you should buy this camera.  Another Loftek is at the back door.  It records me via FTP about once in 5 passes through it's range of motion.FYI : I have a much more expense Y-Cam bullet at my front door.  It usually FTP's about 7 pictures of a person walking down my 15 foot drive.  I just used it to catch a thief that broke into my house last week.  Thank goodness I had the Y-Cam.  I installed the Loftek's afterwards to monitor the driveway and back door.  These cameras are useless to me.

Reviews.Title: Great camera with above average day-time image quality
Reviews.Author: Luong Tran
Reviews.Content: Product performs as expected.  Picture quality during the day is surprisingly good.  There are some shadowing issues during the night, but overall the images are workable.

Reviews.Title: Good camera!
Reviews.Author: Dale Knox
Reviews.Content: Very sturdy and responsive.  Easy to setup.  Does a great job.  Really enjoying. I would recommend this item.  Both day and night.

Reviews.Title: Still Trying
Reviews.Author: DEWDENVER "DEW"
Reviews.Content: After 6 months still trying to hook up.  Needs a static IP address that our modem/router doesn't have.  Guess we have to go to internet provider.  Hiring someone to hook up as tired of spending the time figuring out.

Reviews.Title: Good Resolution. Not waterproof.
Reviews.Author: Adam D Millsap
Reviews.Content: This camera had better resolution than the pan and tilt IP cam I use with the same software. I used it with Ispy which works great. It was also easily setup with foscams iphone app which was nice. That's all great..........unless you are using this outdoor camera outdoors. I agree with other reviewers that the connectors on the back of the camera are not watertight. I was receiving network interference which I had traced to this camera. When I went to check it out I found a housing full of water. For the money it's a pretty good camera, so I wouldn't mind doping it up with a little silicone and moving on, but this one is toast.

Reviews.Title: Not crazy about the firmware
Reviews.Author: Ronald W. Springer
Reviews.Content: See my comments about the Loftek CXS 2200.Additionally, there has to be a better way to get power to the unit. It's supposed to be weatherproof, but the connections generally have to remain outside where moisture can enter - I heavily wrapped the connections with fusible electrical tape and was able to run the 'power' cord through the weather strip gap in our casement style windows.The camera works great, and is streaming on line @ ronscastle.us (does not work with Internet Explorer 8+)

Reviews.Title: Find another outdoor camera
Reviews.Author: John H. Ritchie
Reviews.Content: I bought my first Loftek Nexus 543 surveillance camera a year ago, you can tell by the slight purple tinge or as one reviewer wrote lilac colored exterior.  This camera hands down is great, especially for the cost -- and it still works great today.  Recently I bought two more Nexus 543 cameras only to be really disappointed.  One camera has a focus issue, everything is fuzzy and night-time viewing is all but useless.  The other new camera has to be rebooted several times to get rid of a ghastly negative image that it resorts to intermittently.  It is bright pink and green -- rebooting the camera seems to be the only way to fix it when it happens - I may create a routine to reboot it everyday just as a precaution.  Besides the obvious loss of quality, these new cameras are indeed silver in color.We all know that over the lifespan of a product that companies do rework and downgrade components to save on manufacturing cost.  The quality of this camera has suffered due to that.  My old Nexus 543 has better image day and night over the two new Nexus 543s I just bought.  The mounting hardware on the new cameras is inferior to the mounting assembly that came with my old Nexus 543 which I still use, even though I have moved it countless times.In short, don't buy the new Nexus 543 camera, if you can find an old "Lilac" colored one, invest in that -- it will probably last forever.

Reviews.Title: Wrong Power Adapter Shipped / Did not work with universal power adapter
Reviews.Author: Omega X
Reviews.Content: First of all this was shipped with the WRONG power supply adapter tip (male tip) making it unusable unless you did like me and tried using a universal power adapter.  I used only 5 volts making sure the amperage and polarity were correct and still didn't work. I own FOUR of the pan tilt zoom cameras from the same manufacturer so I know how to set these things up really well unless of course you aren't given the correct power adapter to begin with! Please check your quality control and I hope if I do get a replacement one it will come with the right power supply tip!  Geeze now I have to wait another 2 weeks to get my camera set up!UPDATE: I did receive a full refund of the purchase price for the camera, BUT I had to pay out of pocket $13 for shipping it back which is absolutely poor customer service considering the camera was shipped defective (both the wrong power supply and broken camera) from the beginning! Reviews.Content: Bought the Loftek 53 with the intent of using it out of doors. Almost immediately the lens fogged and moisture collected inside the infra red lens. Then the body of the camera filled with water. Inside the camera was two or three anti moisture packs. Even for a cheap camera this one is absolutely and totally worthless. If there were a minus rating I would give it a minus 5.

Reviews.Content: Your cameras SUCK! I ordered one from amazon and out of the box the camera included the WRONG power supply, and when I took a power supply from another camera all it would do is make a noise like motor was running.

Reviews.Title: Good product at  a good price
Reviews.Author: Lyle Giese
Reviews.Content: It's a good product for the price and offers decent viewability of outdoor areas.  I use it to monitor the front door where my home office is on a lower level.  Makes it easy to see if I need to run up to answer the door or if a delivery person is running back to his truck after dropping off a package.

Reviews.Title: Device DOA
Reviews.Author: benjaminw
Reviews.Content: The device powered on but did not retrieve a DHCP address via the LAN interface.  At no point did the device register a MAC address on my router.  I've tested with numerous IP based cameras and while they all seem to have their faults, this is the first one that failed to retrieve a DHCP address via LAN interface.

Reviews.Title: Not worth getting
Reviews.Author: Ronald D. Kercher
Reviews.Content: I (unfortunately) have purchased several of these cameras to monitor my alpaca barns.  The cameras at first seemed pretty good.  Night vision is fair. The main problem is they (as a whole) infrequently work.  Support is awful.  After a few days of submitting a problem ticket a cryptic email response comes and instructions are to send screen shots, ip settings, etc.  Then a few days or a week later the response comes back to reset to factory settings, reinstall active x, etc.,, etc., etc.,  Then when the camera still doesn't work they want you to give access to your network to 'troubleshoot'.  Sorry...but I'm not granting access to my network to any stranger.  If you keep complaining and ask to have the camera replaced or refunded you get to go through this entire exercise all over again and the camera still won't work and weeks or months have passed so forget about asking Amazon to take them back. These cameras are unreliable and imho a waste of your money.

Reviews.Title: Not The Best
Reviews.Author: Linus69
Reviews.Content: My least favorite outdoor IP Camera of the several brands I own.
