Reviews.Title: False advertising
Reviews.Author: araknid_x "araknid_x"
Reviews.Content: This camera is advertised as 802.11n compatible (see Technical Details: Other Protocol:802.11b/g/n) but it is not - this is according to a response from their email customer service (they did promptly respond overnight).I was able to set up the camera using the provided S/W on Disk, the set up is extremely clunky. There's something wrong with the camera's DHCP client, it does not work well with the Static DNS I tried setting up on my Router, you can specify a fixed IP address on the camera though. As far as I'm concerned this should be plug & play with auto DHCP - I should not even have to use some S/W to get it set up with an IP address. I was able to activate the motion sensing, ftp, email just fine. It would not email me pictures though, it only sends out a notification when it detects motion.I had a lot of trouble getting wireless to work, as mentioned earlier I found out the hard way that this thing does not work with 802.11n. Next I tried 802.11g and it would not initially work with that either, it turns out that it uses a hidden MAC address for Wifi (it only shows the wired MAC address on its Device Info page). I have MAC address filtering set up on my Router and even though I added the MAC address it showed on its device info page because it used a different MAC address on wifi it would not work. I had to turn off MAC filtering to get this thing on the network and had to look through the wireless devices page of my Router to get the wifi MAC address of the Camera. Once I added that to the MAC address filter I was able to turn MAC address filtering back on.Build-wise, it feels solid. The picture quality is nothing to write home about but it is a security camera so I did not have much expectation there. Infrared is Ok, you are not going to be able to recognize faces with the infrared it will only help to detect motion.To view images you have to log on to the camera with a userid & password, it worked with Google Chrome, Firefox and Safari on my iphone. for Internet Explorer it wanted to download some plug-in which I did not and so I could not see images from that browser.To sum up, if you are not a tech savvy person please avoid this camera and save yourself a lot of hassle.-->Update 8/31/11I'd like to correct the part about not getting images in email. Turns out that it can and does send out images with email when detecting motion. The imageless emails I got happened to be notifications that it sends out with the network's external IP address changes.

Reviews.Title: 2nd one dead now too... Customer Service SUCKS!
Reviews.Author: Dave the Pear
Reviews.Content: Update #5: Amazon fixed the issue...Update #4: Amazon site says to contact seller, seller says contact manufacturer, manufacturer says contact seller, and finally, seller says to contact Amazon! Now if THAT isn't a runaround, I don't know WHAT IS! The customer service is absolutely horrible, if I can even consider it "service". The power supply went out, that should have been my first clue, but I ordered a replacement, only to watch AND HEAR the camera continue to die. I'm apparently stuck with two of these dead things, maybe I can use their carcass to create a better outdoor camera with non-chinese guts in it. mad mad mad!IF YOU DO BUY A LAUGH-TECH CAMERA, DO NOT BUY IT FROM NEVERBUY (Everbuy)! If it goes haywire, it's not their problem!Here's their email about the in-warranty request:"Dear Dave,This is the everbuy customer service.We are sorry that this camera has some tech problems.Because your order is FBA order,so we suggest you to contact amazon customer service to give you full refund.Best regards,"Amazon's:"Return Window expired on November 22, 2012.If you return this item, you will receive a partial refund according to our Returns Policy. Shipping fees will not be refunded, and you will need to pay for return shipping."I'll likely end up paying MORE to get rid of it! Is this customer service?!Update #3: Now it's just clicking... and when it clicks, loudly, the colors get weird...Update #2: Basically it's a toy. The thing likes to "flash" while you're watching it, causing it to "sense motion" and upload 1000's of pictures as the thing goes bright-dim-bright-dim-bright-dim-bright-dim-bright-dim-bright-dim and the ONLY thing you can do about it is to change it from 640x480 to 320x240.Original review: I certainly like this thing better than its outdoor ptz counterpart (ordered at same time, see other reviews). It was easy to set up and use, night vision is sufficient. Why did I get another one? The last one just died... guessing the lifespan of new one will be roughly the same, 8 months? I'm still unsure why I purchased another one when I didn't like this one!

Reviews.Title: Pure Junk.  Setup software disables network devices
Reviews.Author: W
Reviews.Content: Actually, this camera is coming back -- I am going to return it because I cannot make it work correctly.More importantly and most disturbing is that the setup software provided with this camera damaged -- actually destroyed -- the settings for several devices on my network, requiring me to completely set those systems up again.This happened twice.  It was no fluke.In setting up the camera, and using the setup software provided, and when scanning the network to find the camera, that software wiped out the settings in a powerline ethernet system such that that system stopped working, and required a complete reset to factory settings and a new setup in order for them to work again.  I never did get the camera to work on my home network -- not even wired.After this happened the first time, I then set up the camera on an isolated network, using an isolated laptop, connected by ethernet to an isolated router.  The only devices connected to that router were the laptop and the camera.  I was able to get the camera working, but only when wired.  The camera WOULD NOT connect to the isolated network wirelessly.Having demonstrated that the camera would indeed work, I then attempted to set the camera up on my home network.  Once again I used the scanning software, but the camera was never found.  Again, the camera would not even work wired.BUT -- once again, the entire powerline ethernet devices, (which were not even in play for the camera setup as the camera was hard wired to the router via a switch, but data was not transported via the powerline system in this configuration) -- once again the setup configuration of that powerline ethernet system was wiped out, would not function, had to be set up from scratch again.So -- there is s 1:1 correlation of using the scanning software and the powerline system being disabled.  Twice.  Make that correlation 2:2 then.  Results in a pretty high X^2 value.By the way -- both times this happened, the wireless router had to be cold reset, and the wireless access point in a remote part of my home had to be cold reset, because none of the 7 computers on the network would communicate with the router wired or wirelessly -- this in addition to the powerline system being totally disabled.  Everything with an IP address on the network -- some 27 devices (computers, VoIP adapters, NAS drives, network printers, Slingbox, alarm system IP interface, smartphone WiFi connections, weather station) -- including both dynamic and static IP addresses -- had to be reset.  The system didn't just not work on my network -- it DISABLED numerous devices on my network -- TWICE.And -- I never did get the wireless side of the camera to work.  Wired yes, but only when on an isolated network.  Wireless -- no way.For the few minutes that the camera did provide images while wired, looks like it might have been an OK solution for what I was looking for.  If only it worked wirelessly as advertised  ..........  and didn't destroy every connection on my network.But I just WILL NOT tolerate somebody sending software into my network that damages settings and disables devices.  I haven't had to deal with issues like this since I fought with SCSI cards and IRQ settings.  Unbelievable.Note to manufacturer:  Let me know when you guys figure out what plug-n-play means.  Till then, your camera is coming back.I WILL NOT have anything in my network that has such wrecklessly designed software that disables other devices in or on the network.
